citation.article-title: Sphingobium quisquiliarum sp. nov., a hexachlorocyclohexane (HCH)-degrading bacterium isolated from an HCH-contaminated soil
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Sphingobium quisquiliarum sp. nov.
Sphingobium quisquiliarum (quis.qui.li.a′rum. L. gen. pl. n. quisquiliarum of refuse, rubbish, trash, referring to the isolation of the type strain from an HCH dump site).
Gram-negative, aerobic, non-flagellated, non-motile, non-spore-forming, rod-shaped bacterium (2.0–2.3 μm long and 0.5–1.5 μm in diameter).
Colonies are yellow, small (diameter 0.1–1.5 mm on LB agar after 48 h of incubation at 28 °C), entire, smooth, circular, convex and opaque.
The optimum temperature, pH and NaCl concentration for growth are 28 °C, pH 7 and 1 % (w/v).
Nitrate is not reduced to nitrite.
Can hydrolyse aesculin and Tween 20 but not Tween 80, gelatin, starch or casein.

Acid is produced from d-glucose, galactose, xylose, fructose, sucrose, cellobiose, raffinose, sorbitol and trehalose (after a long period of incubation) but not from lactose, mannose, myo-inositol, adonitol or malonate.
Sensitive to amikacin, chloramphenicol, ciprofloxacin, gentamicin, kanamycin, oxytetracycline, polymyxin B, rifampicin, tetracycline and vancomycin but resistant to ampicillin.
Degrades α-, β-, γ- and δ-HCH isomers in liquid culture.
Major polar lipids are phosphatidylglycerol, diphosphatidylglycerol and sphingoglycolipid.
The major fatty acids are summed feature 8 (18 : 1ω7c and/or 18 : 1ω6c), 16 : 0 and 14 : 0 2-OH.
The type strain, P25T (=MTCC 9472T =CCM 7543T), was isolated from HCH-contaminated soil at Ummari village, Lucknow, India.
